Thirdly, if the colours made by a Prisme placed at the 
Entrance of a beame of Light into a darkened room be 
Successively cast on a Second Prisme placed at a great distance 
from the former, in such manner that they are all alike 
incident upon it; the Second Prism may be So inclined to the 
Incident rayes, that those wch are of a blew colour, shall be all 
reflected by it, and yet those of a red colour pretty copiously 
transmitted. Now if the reflexion be caused by the parts of 
Air or Glasse, I would ask, why at the same Obliquity of
incidence the blew Should wholly impinge on those parts So 
as to be all reflected, & yet the red find pores enough to 
be in great measure transmitted. Fourthly, where two Glasses 
touch one another, there is no Sensible reflexion, as was declared 
in the 1st Observac[i]on, & yet I See no reason, why the rayes 
Should not impinge on the parts of Glasse, when contiguous to 
another Glasse, as much as when contiguous to Air. Fiftly, when 
the top of a water Bubble (in the 17th Observac[i]on) by the 
continual<s>ling<\s> subsiding & exhaling of the water grew very thin, there 
was Such alittle & almost insensible quantity of Light reflected 
from it, that it appeared intensely black; whereas round about 
that black Spott, where the water was thicker, the reflexion 
was so strong as to make the water Seeme very white. Nor 
is it onely at the least thicknesse of thin Plates or Bubbles 
that there is no manifest reflexion, but at many other thicknesses 
continually greater and greater. For in the 15th Observac[i]on 
the rayes of the same colour were by turnes transmitted 
at one thickness, & reflected at another thickness for an 
intermediate number of Successions. And yet in the sup [er]ficies 
of the third body, where it is of any one thicknesse, there are as 
many parts for the rayes to impinge on, as where it is of any 
other thicknesse.
Lastly if reflexion were caused by the parts of
